p: The issue of the lack of knowledge is also present for research on the effectiveness of controlling populations using different methods. Utilization as a control method is becoming popular in many areas such as Djibouti, Ethiopia and Kenya. However, despite many reports showing how much monetary benefit Prosopis has provided, there is no information on how successful this approach is for controlling Prosopis invasions. There are also conflicting ideas on the role and success of biological control in Australia and South Africa and further work is needed ( Zachariades et al. 2011 ). There is scope for identifying and potentially releasing additional biological control agents to improve control success in areas where this has been limited until now, such as in South Africa ( Zachariades et al. 2011 ). Research is needed to identify novel solutions to aid the dilemma of management and contentious issues regarding invasive Prosopis globally. These include methods that retain the benefits, but reduce the impacts substantially.
